text.headline: The Birth of Unix
text.text: Ken Thompson and Dennis Ritchie create Unix at AT&T Bell Labs. Its philosophy of 'small, modular programs' and its file system structure would become the blueprint for Linux decades later.

media.caption: The pioneers: Thompson and Ritchie at a PDP-11.

text.headline: The GNU Project Announced
text.text: Richard Stallman announces the GNU Project with the goal of creating a completely free, Unix-compatible operating system. By 1991, they had almost every component readyâ€”except for the kernel.

media.caption: The GNU project provided the 'userland' tools that would eventually be paired with Linux.

text.headline: MINIX Released
text.text: Andrew S. Tanenbaum releases MINIX for educational use. While it wasn't fully open, it provided the sandbox where a young Linus Torvalds would first learn how an OS functions.

media.caption: The 'Teacher': MINIX sparked the curiosity of developers worldwide.

text.headline: The Famous 'Just a Hobby' Email
text.text: Linus Torvalds posts to the comp.os.minix newsgroup, announcing his new kernel. He famously noted it 'won't be big and professional like gnu,' unaware it would soon run the world.

media.caption: The post that started a revolution.

text.headline: Linux Adopts the GPL
text.text: By moving Linux to the GNU General Public License, Linus ensured the code would remain free forever. This allowed the GNU tools and the Linux kernel to finally merge into a complete OS: GNU/Linux.

media.caption: The GPL: The legal 'engine' of the open-source movement.

text.headline: Debian is Founded
text.text: Ian Murdock founds Debian, a project focused on being the 'universal operating system.' It would later become the foundation for Ubuntu and thousands of other projects.

media.caption: Debian: The grandfather of modern Linux distributions.

text.headline: Linux Kernel 1.0.0
text.text: After three years of rapid development, Linux reaches version 1.0. It was now a stable, networked multitasking OS that could challenge commercial Unix systems.

media.caption: Linux 1.0 was roughly 176,000 lines of code.

text.headline: The Enterprise Pivot
text.text: IBM, Oracle, and Intel announce formal support for Linux. This killed the stigma that Linux was 'just for hobbyists' and began its takeover of the server room.

media.caption: IBM's billion-dollar investment in Linux changed the industry forever.

text.headline: Ubuntu: Linux for Human Beings
text.text: Canonical releases Ubuntu 4.10 (Warty Warthog). It prioritized ease of use and a predictable release cycle, bringing Linux to millions of desktop users.

media.caption: Ubuntu's original 'brown' aesthetic focused on simplicity.

text.headline: Android: Linux in Your Pocket
text.text: Google announces Android. Based on the Linux kernel, it would go on to become the most-installed operating system in the world, proving Linux's incredible versatility.

media.caption: The T-Mobile G1: The first commercial device running a Linux-based phone OS.

text.headline: The 'Impossible' Twist: WSL
text.text: Microsoft releases the Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL). After years of rivalry, the two systems merged as Microsoft embraced Linux for developers and cloud services.

media.caption: Microsoft Loves Linux: An era-defining shift in corporate strategy.

text.headline: 100% Supercomputer Dominance
text.text: Linux reaches a milestone: it now powers every single one of the top 500 supercomputers on Earth. Its performance and customizability remain unmatched in high-performance computing.

media.caption: The Fugaku Supercomputer: Powered entirely by Linux.

text.headline: The Steam Deck & Gaming
text.text: Valve releases the Steam Deck, running a Linux-based SteamOS. Using 'Proton,' it allows thousands of Windows-native games to run flawlessly, signaling the end of the 'no games on Linux' era.

media.caption: Linux is now a powerhouse in mainstream portable gaming.
